summary: A letter from Senator Ben Sasse to Attorney General William Barr regarding the apparent suicide of Jeffrey Epstein while in federal custody. The letter expresses outrage over the failure to prevent Epstein's death, demands investigations into the circumstances, and raises concerns about securing evidence against Epstein's co-conspirators.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.role: United States Senator, Chairman of Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Oversight
persons.context: Author of the letter to Attorney General Barr, demanding accountability and investigations following Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody.

persons.name: William P. Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Recipient of the letter, responsible for the Department of Justice and the investigations into Epstein's death and the handling of his case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The wealthy financier indicted for running an international child sex trafficking ring, found dead by apparent suicide in federal custody on the date of the letter.

connections.description: Senator Sasse is writing officially to Attorney General Barr to demand action and answers regarding the Epstein case.
Senator Sasse, in his oversight role, is holding the DOJ accountable for its handling of Epstein's prosecution and custody.
As Attorney General, Barr is ultimately responsible for the Department of Justice's prosecution and custody of Epstein.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Found Dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead by apparent suicide in federal Bureau of Prisons custody.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on federal charges related to an international child sex trafficking ring.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: The Department of Justice entered into a non-prosecution agreement with Epstein, which was later investigated for being mishandled.

events.title: Previous Suicide Attempt
events.description: Epstein was found injured and semi-conscious in his cell from a possible suicide attempt less than three weeks before his death.

locations: U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, DC 20530
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead by apparent suicide in federal custody on August 10, 2019.
Epstein had been injured in a possible suicide attempt in his cell less than three weeks prior to his death and may have been placed on, then taken off, suicide watch.
Senator Sasse demands two investigations: one into the Bureau of Prisons' mismanagement of Epstein's incarceration, and another into possible criminal activity surrounding that mismanagement.
The letter expresses grave concern that Epstein's death deprives victims of justice and makes it harder to hold his co-conspirators and other powerful men accountable.
Senator Sasse calls for the immediate securing of all evidence related to Epstein's co-conspirators to prevent it from being squandered.
